author: Kathy Routliffe
title: Cupich preaches freedom from fear, support for refugees during Regina Dominican Mass
text:
Suburbs Wilmette Life Wilmette News Cupich preaches freedom from fear, support for refugees during Regina Dominican Mass Kathy Routliffe , celebrating a Mass at Regina Dominican High School in Wilmette on Monday, urged his young listeners to avoid fear and the herd mentality he said it generates by aiming for the spiritual community that is part of Catholic education.
Over the weekend, Cupich condemned President Donald Trump 's executive order mandating travel restrictions on people from seven Muslim-majority countries by calling it "a dark moment in U.S. history." On Monday, he referenced the issue during the service at the all-girls high school. 
Telling his audience that they must care for all people, whether they are the unborn, the homeless or the convicted, the cardinal added to that list "the refugee who now is being kept out of our country because of an executive order. 
"These are not just political issues," he said. "They are human issues." 
In his homily, Cupich used the story of Jesus freeing a possessed man from evil spirits by sending the spirits into a herd of pigs, which then ran off a cliff and drowned. People who live in isolation from others can fall prey to fear and thus to such a herd mentality, he said. 
"People who are afraid want to dive into a feeling of 'us vs. them,'" he said. "The life of a herd has no destiny except to be driven off a cliff." 
Cupich said those in a spiritual community like Regina, which is sponsored by the Adrian Dominican Sisters, should reach out to those who struggle with fears, adding, "it is important to let people know they are not alone." 
The cardinal, who is helping Chicago-area Catholic schools celebrate Catholic Schools Week, joined Regina Dominican as the high school kicked its own week of events with the Mass, held at Regina's O'Shaughnessy Theatre. The service drew alumni, family, and school supporters, as well as elementary students from St. Joan of Arc School in Skokie and The School of Saints Faith, Hope and Charity in Winnetka. 
Christine Finzer of Chicago and Buffy McNabola Rock of Lake Forest said they were alumni and former Wilmette residents. Both praised Regina's tradition of community. 
"I love the school," Rock said. "I think it's a place of family, and community and friendship." 
Sister Dot Dempsey, an Adrian Dominican sister, said she attended the mass from the south side of Chicago. Dempsey, who said a niece attended Regina, said, "it's a wonderful school." 
Regina President Elizabeth Pattara Schuster said the Mass and Cupich's visit have been in the works for roughly a month: "We've been trying to have him come and bless the auditorium, and we are so glad that it worked out." 
The auditorium underwent roughly $1.2 million in renovations, in part to make the space ADA compliant, Schuster said. Work, which was funded by Regina's "The Gateway to Leadership" capital campaign, began in June 2016 and was completed shortly before the end of October, Regina Communications Director Katie Pins said. Work included abating asbestos, creating a more accessible floor plan, adding more comfortable seats and replacing the space's original floor, she said.
